captions.text:
Flying in a 747 from one side of the earth
to the exact opposite side would take about

22 hours… and while I know there's a bit
of rock in the way, that's really going the
long way round.

So what if we did dig a hole all the way through
the earth, through the center, and jumped
in?

Well, Michael, you probably would't make it
very far - that's because of the Coriolis

effect (which is why a ball curves weirdly
when you toss it while riding a merry go round

and why hurricanes always spin counterclockwise
in the northern hemisphere). At the equator,

the earth (and you on it) is rotating eastwards
at 1670 km/hr. As you go deeper, the bits

of earth around you are still spinning around
once per day, but they don't have as far to

travel so they're going at slower and slower
speeds. If you jumped into a vertical shaft,

you'd soon be traveling east faster than the
rock around you so that after falling only

a few kilometers, you'd crash into the eastern
wall. It might not be a disaster, but some

miners near Lake Superior tried to test this
by dropping cannon balls down a mile-long
shaft - and the balls never reached the bottom.

OK, so what if the tunnel went from pole to
pole, so the Coriolis effect didn't apply,

and let's also assume that there's no air
resistance, or friction

Ok. Since the earth's mass is more concentrated
close to the middle, gravity would pull you

down with roughly the same amount of force
for the first 3000 km, or halfway to the center

of the earth - this familiar, constant force
would accelerate you until you were falling

8km every second, and the trip halfway to
the middle of the earth would only take 13

minutes. Soon after, you'd reach the earth's
outer core, and this is the point in your

journey where the pull of gravity would be
strongest - but only slightly stronger than
the force we're used to on the surface.

As you continued to fall closer to the center,
so much of the earth's mass would now be above

you that it would begin to seriously cancel
out the attraction of the mass below, and

the pull would weaken until you reached the
center. Here, you'd experience no gravitational

pull at all - or rather, the earth would be
pulling on you the same amount in all directions,

so you could float freely around with no sense
of "up" or "down". Except, remember, that

you'd be speeding past at 22,000 miles per
hour, or 6 miles a second.

Once you passed the center, the whole process
would reverse and you'd gradually slow, pulled

down (or is it up?) weakly at first and then
more strongly, until when you got to the other

side, you'd stop moving and could step out
on the surface, a mere 37 minutes, or one
dryer cycle, later.

Of course, the deepest we've ever been able
to dig is the Kola Superdeep borehole in Russia.

But it only went down 12km, which is only
two thirds the length of Manhattan. They had

to stop because it got too hot: 180°C. And
this is sort of the problem with digging a

hole through earth - earth is hot, and molten
in the middle. You can't just dig a hole through

it with shovels. But here's a question: wasn't
the middle of earth wasn't all "liquidy",

what if earth was hollow, but weighed the
same?

Well, with its entire mass concentrated in
a thin shell right under our feet, the earth

wouldn't have a magnetic field any more, because
that comes from the molten iron core. So we'd

be totally vulnerable to radiation from the
solar wind and storms, and this means we'd

see the aurora EVERYWHERE. Look! The NorthernSouthernEastern
lights!

And if you jumped inside the hollow earth
to escape the solar storm? Well, gravity from

the different parts of the spherical earth-shell
would perfectly cancel out and you'd float

freely about inside as if the earth weren't
there at all! Of course, you'd better bring

a space suit, because there's not nearly enough
air ON earth to fill up the entire INSIDE

of earth. But what if the entire inside of
the hollow earth were covered with mirrors?
Henry, that's ridiculous… for now

Ok, so back outside of the earth, we wouldn't
really notice much difference from a gravitational

perspective - falling things would still accelerate
at 9.8 m/s^2, a baseball would follow the

same trajectory, and the moon would follow
the same orbit around the earth.

Hey Henry, let's go to outer space, right
now. Bring your gun - this'll all make sense
later. C'mon.

Oh, and you're coming too. Click this annotation
to head over to my channel, Vsauce, to see

the rest of our adventures. I'll see you over
there.

title: What if the Earth were Hollow?

comments.author: Eisen “Eisenheim” Heim

comments.text:
Wait a minute... If you were falling through the earth from pole to pole, 
wouldn't you loose momentum before reaching the other side and then fall 
back through the hole to the beginning of the jump, again loosing even more 
momentum before reaching the original hole and jump?

And this continues until you loose all momentum and you are in the middle 
of the core just floating there, assuming the core doesn't vaporize you and 
for the sake of argument.﻿
comments.author: avsiii

comments.text:
+avsiii This would be the case if there was drag involved, but the 
specifically address that by noting that in their mind experiment, all the 
air has been removed.

Momentum is inherently conserved, so given no outside forces (like drag), 
once you reach the center, you have built up the exact amount of momentum 
to carry you to the opposite side - an equal distance away from center as 
you started with. Given a perfectly spherical Earth, you would JUST reach 
the other side.

comments.author: rj34567891

comments.text:
By the time they get to the center, they are already going fast enough to 
pass through and reach the other side.  Imagine you were in the center, and 
you wanted to throw something "up".  Imagine that you could throw it with 
8km/s of velocity.  How high would it go?  That's essentially what is 
happening by the time the falling object reaches the center.  There is no 
reason for it to magically stop in the center.  By the time it gets there, 
it has built up 8km/s of velocity, so it has all that kinetic energy to 
reach the opposite side of Earth.

Think of it this way :

If you were standing on the surface of the Earth, and you had a friend 
climb a ladder and drop a rock from the top of that ladder 100 meters above 
the surface, and then you were asked to measure the velocity it has when it 
hits the Earth, you would find that if you threw that rock back up toward 
your friend at the top of that ladder with the same velocity it landed 
with, it would have just enough energy to reach the exact height your 
friend dropped it from.  The same concept applies to this mind experiment.  
The object falling toward the center of Earth will have some velocity when 
it reaches the center.  The moment it passes the center, it is as if it was 
thrown back up the hole with the same velocity it had when it reached the 
center, ergo - it will have enough energy to reach the same height it was 
dropped from - and on a perfectly spherical Earth (which is assumed here), 
it would perfectly reach the other surface "lip" of the Earth.

comments.text:
If you tunneled through the Earth anywhere but at the axis of rotation 
(pole to pole), then the coriolis effect would cause you to hit the wall of 
your tunnel on the way down.  The effect would be more pronounced the 
closer you were to the equator - and at its greatest at the equator.

forces that oppose gravity; not gravity itself. Even if the Earth were not 
a perfect sphere, inside or out, you'd be in free fall, and you do not feel 
gravity in free fall.

comments.author: yolodench

comments.text:
+yolodench No you wouldnt. Acceleration is a CHANGE in velocity; not just 
an INCREASE in velocity. Yes, you would be accelerating constantly, but 
half the time in one direction, and half the time in the opposite direction.

When you first jump in, you are accelerating toward the center. You are 
moving TOWARD the center so your velocity increases. Once you pass the 
center, you would STILL be accelerating toward the center, but you are 
moving AWAY from the center, so the acceleration slows you down once you 
pass center. Then the process goes in reverse - oscillating back and forth. 
8km/s would be your velocity each time you pass center, and this is as fast 
as you would ever go.
comments.author: Willoughby Krenzteinburg

comments.text:
Because you are always accelerating toward the center of mass of the 
Earth.  Once you pass the center, that center is then opposite your 
direction of motion so the acceleration then slows you down.

Guillaume Roy - allow replies to comments if you want answers to your 
questions.  You would expect that the gravitational force would get 
stronger and stronger as you tunnel into the Earth IF the density of the 
Earth were uniform.  This is not the case.  The density of the core is much 
higher than the density of the crust and mantle, so for about a 1/3 of the 
trip, you are getting closer to much more dense material, therefore - for a 
while, the force would get stronger until you start to pass into the more 
dense material - then it would start decreasing.﻿

comments.author: Paul Bedford

comments.text:
+drake don
Ok, I thought this was a different video about a tunnel through the Earth.  
Calm down. 

If you were inside the Earth at the equator, and the Earth were spinning at 
its current rate, you could 'stand' on the inside edge of the wall and feel 
as though you weighed about half a pound (if your mass is 75 kg).  In other 
words, the centripetal and centrifugal forces would be a little over 2 
Newtons - one in each direction of course.  The apparent acceleration would 
be about .03 m/s².

This is no different than centrifugal force is right now on the outside of 
the Earth.  A 75kg man weighs about a half a pound less at the equator than 
he does at the poles, so to answer your question - nothing DIFFERENT 
happens.  It's just that centrifugal and centripetal would work in opposite 
directions on the INSIDE of the rotating hollow Earth.

Happy?

comments.author: Dark Matter101

comments.text:
The source of Earth's magnetic field has been a mystery. The Inner Sun at 
the center of Earth is the mysterious power source behind the Earth's 
magnetic field.
There are entry caverns all over the Earth, where interactions can take 
place. Only some are currently open. Nikola Tesla, the genius inventor of 
electrical technology, is now living inside the Hollow Earth. He began to 
receive information in the latter part of the 1800's and discovered that: 
“electric power is everywhere present in unlimited quantities and can drive 
the world's machinery without the need of coal, oil, gas or any other of 
the common fuels”. In the 1930's the tunnel entrances and passageways were 
closed off by the Hollow Earth civilizations because “corporations” at that 
time were misusing Tesla's technology to gain entrance into the Inner 
Earth. The Hollow Earth's two main Portals are at the Holes at the Poles, 
which were closed off in the year 2000 because our governments were setting 
detonations at the Poles to blow open entrances into their world. They have 
installed a magnetic force field around Earth's polar openings to further 
camouflage the entrances. This way, the openings are protected from air and 
land sightings. In the past there were entrances to the Library of 
Porthologos on the surface. One such entrance was the Library of 
Alexandria, which was destroyed by fire in A.D. 642.﻿

comments.author: WhyteLis21

comments.text:
+WhyteLis21 "Is impossible training possible?"

Anyway, no, you would die guaranteed at less than 20 times; almost 
instantly if you're close to 20.

At 1000 times, you would likely just smear into wet goop.
I'm fairly certain no planet anywhere near that massive exists anyway.
comments.author: OatmealTheCrazy

comments.text:
+Sean Cauffiel doing the impossible training on a planet over 1000 strong 
then earth. Is that even really even possible?
comments.author: WhyteLis21

comments.text:
+OatmealTheCrazy Fine. Real answer.... at the center of Earth, you would 
experience gravity about the same as you would experience it in orbit. 
Given that astronauts lose fitness and bone density during long stays in 
microgravity no matter how much they exercise, I'd say working out at the 
center of Earth would work against you. If you want to get strong, move to 
Jupiter.
comments.author: Sean Cauffiel

comments.author: Sean Cauffiel

comments.text:
+Sean Cauffiel But there would be no atmosphere to strike as the oceans 
would have evaporated and all life would have ceased to exist. Earth would 
be a baron planet.
comments.author: Mark Scott

comments.text:
The Earth's magnetic field doesn't trap charged particles, it deflects most 
of it, and concentrates the rest at the poles. The aurora is not produced 
by the magnetic field, it is merely placed by it. Without the 
magnetosphere, aurora would be produced where ever charged particles strike 
the Earth's atmosphere.... which would be everywhere.
